summary: STAR WARS ISN’T A TALE OF GODS AND MONSERS - AT LEAST NOT ANYMORE or a meta nobody asked for At the end of the day, it’s a story...
body:
STAR WARS ISN’T A TALE OF GODS AND MONSERS - AT LEAST NOT ANYMORE or a meta nobody asked for

At the end of the day, it’s a story about humanity in its most vulnerable ways and extreme consequences, it deals with dark desires, family, love, hope and pain among others. If you think about star wars this way, then the force isn’t just magic, it is our ability to manipulate, create, build our future and shape our present. Ben Solo is afraid of his future and thinks his present is just pain, and he is tortured by the thought of what he can do with this power. He is so scared that he puts a mask to scare the pain away… until he is in pain himself. This is one of the most powerful, difficult and sad truths of the human experience: you can’t save anyone if you don’t save yourself first, and even then you can’t save everyone.

Little Ben Solo was probably a kind-hearted and sensitive kid, so what could bring such child to the dark side? Fear and heartbreak, and I am not talking the pain you feel when you break up with your partner, I’m thinking of that kind of heartbreak that makes you lose hope. Rey isn’t better than Kylo, she explores the dark side looking for the answers she wants, but she has hope. Hope is what shaped her life since her childhood: the hope to find her parents, which in her mind is the same as someone who loves you uncoditionally.

And that brings me to love. Love is what can spark up hope, and this is what Kylo is missing. The idea behind the creation of Kylo Ren is someone who doesn’t feel love, who doesn’t feel anything, someone who is numb enough to let his mind wander and never come back to reality. But Kylo Ren is just a product of Ben Solo, Kylo Ren depends on Ben Solo, it’s not the other way around. And Snoke knows it when he tells Kylo to take the mask off, his intent is to hurt the very core of Kylo Ren: Ben Solo.

When Rey meets Kylo Ren, she feels that all hope is not lost, and why is it not lost yet? Because Ben Solo is still alive, under all the layers he built to protect himself from pain. And the truth is that you need to learn that some things can be saved and some things cannot, this is the lesson that Ben Solo still hasn’t learnt. Rey is one step ahead of him, but she’s still not there yet: she still longs for her parents.

This kind of behaviour, this love hunger, is as human as it can get. Rey and Ben aren’t enemies, they are two people trying to find love, someone to lean on.

Okay, I’ll stop here.

blog.name: johnnyclash87
blog.title: Fandoms Books Social Consciousness
blog.description:
I'll come up with a better title eventually.

Short and sweet I'm a nerd/geek. I listen to punk. I'm a feminist. I'm an lgbtq ally. I'm a wanna be superhero/adventurer. Because I talk a lot about race and racism I should probably clarify that I’m white and male.?

One of the things I love is how speculative fiction can be used to talk about serious topics. Which is what this will mostly be about. Along with just some fun things.

summary: I think in the GAR position and experience and skill are valued over rank. Rank is based on random things like if a Clone was...
body:
I think in the GAR position and experience and skill are valued over rank. Rank is based on random things like if a Clone was “trained” or “genetically built” to be a commander or sergeant or what not.

But when shit hits the fan and half the battalion is dead including the officers and NCOs and SOMEBODY has to take charge, you’re going to look at the one with a little more time on the ground and who can get the job done.

This is why Fives has a closer relationship with Rex than, say, Appo. Appo is a sergeant (later commander) and is placed in charge of half the battalion but that’s only because Krell “by the book” said so. We don’t know Fives rank but we know he’s an ARC Trooper because of his quick and creative thinking. Which is why Fives has no problem telling Rex what’s up, and Rex goes to Fives when he needs shit done and looks away when Fives gets a little “independent”. Not to mention Rex who although ranked as a captain, holds a battalion commander position.

The same practice goes for the 212th. There were probably plenty of Troopers that technically out ranked Waxer. But when Cody needed a platoon leader, he chose the best, someone who had experience taking initiative and working without someone to telling him what to do.

And this isn’t too unlike the real world. If you ask most people who served in the military they’ll tell you nobody gives a rats ass what your rank is. They care more about how many deployments you’ve had.

blog.name: tsaomengde
blog.title: Speak of the devil... [说曹操...]
blog.description: Gabriel Mengde Routh. Author, male, 30, autistic. Technically multifandom, some original writing, more political than I used to be.

summary: So last night I watched TLJ for the first time since it came out in theatres. This was not a decision made lightly.  I am still...
body:
So last night I watched TLJ for the first time since it came out in theatres.

This was not a decision made lightly.  I am still distraught over Carrie’s passing and probably will never stop being so, at least not for the foreseeable future.  This film was also a very difficult one for me, because when it hit theatres and I saw it, I liked it.

I really liked it.  I had problems with it, because there are many problems to be had, but at the end of the day I was keen on it and looked forward to talking about it with people.  Real-life people, sure, but also people in the fandom on here.

My enthusiasm was not shared.

Certainly there were people who liked it, even with its problems, but I saw so much vitriolic anti stuff posted about it.  The film is racist, and if you like it, you’re racist too.  The film is garbage, and if you like it, you’re garbage.  It should be struck from canon.  Rian Johnson should be beaten bloody for his crimes.  And so on and so on.

It was disheartening.  It soured me on writing SW fic, which I had been happily doing again since the beginning of 2016.  Sith Apprentice is still sitting there, unfinished, while I try to rally back into a headspace where I feel good about writing it.  The discourse about TFA was nothing like this.  Mostly I remember criticisms of “it’s too much like ANH,” which is valid, and a lot of wank about Reylo, which I don’t care for but hey, people are allowed to enjoy problematic things.

And so in the spirit of being allowed to enjoy problematic things, I watched it last night.  My wife is in another state giving a presentation for work, so I put the kids to bed, sat alone in the dark, and watched it with headphones on.  I was prepared for it not to hold up.  I was prepared to set aside my initial “a new SW is coming out” enthusiasm from ten months ago and really evaluate it critically.

I still like it.  It holds up.  It’s not a perfect film, or indeed even a mostly (75% or more) good film.  The problems are competing with the good things and they’re basically neck-and-neck.  But these things I can forgive.  I cried when Leia says to Holdo, “No more losses.  I can’t take any more,” and Holdo says, “Yes you can.  You taught *me* how.”  It was a good, peaceful moment by myself, with myself.

People are allowed to criticize and dislike and disagree.  Mark Hamill himself disagrees with the direction the film took with Luke.  Shit, I disagree with it, even though I think it works.  But if I take anything away from this experience, it is a renewed determination to be better about disagreeing cordially.  Not shitting on people for liking something I don’t like.  It’s really, really hard, but I’m going to keep at it.
